Title: Linking forum posts -casebiostat-03-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
For question 19, I'm having trouble understanding that the population relief rates were supported by the hypothesis and how that relates to the explanation given by the Binomial random. Thanks.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Amy! The explanation of the question tells you how the probabilities in the table were calculated. However, to answer the question you just need to look at said probabilities for the row that corresponds to 1 and notice that under H0 and H1 these probabilities are similar and higher than under H2. Best, Francis
Instructor's post : Hi Amy! The explanation of the question tells you how the probabilities in the table were calculated. However, to answer the question you just need to look at said probabilities for the row that corresponds to 1 and notice that under H0 and H1 these probabilities are similar and higher than under H2. Best, Francis
Upvotes:
5

Title: Linking forum posts -casebiostat-03-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
Which of the following causal statements is consistent with the statistical definition of “cause” whether or not the statement is true (Choose all that apply) Are we: Identifying whether or not the statement is true - which could be subject to your hypothesis(understanding of the universe). Identifying which of the statements could be regarded as a statistical question for causality (potential). If the objective is 1, I feel that the question isn't well articulated If the objective is 2, I am having confusion understanding why all of them couldn't be considered as part of the causal definition, as effectively, they are all the same. There is some probable measure of causality. i.e The day of the week could be measured with some potential that it was the cause of death, whether that probability is 0 or not. Any help in clarifying this would be appreciated, many thanks.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Tjad! We are trying to identify which of the statements fit the definition of causality (2). Remember that the definition of cause we are using in this class requires that the 'cause' is a variable we can intervene upon (i.e. we can change somehow). For example, treatment assignment to drug or placebo, which is something we can modify. However, variables like sex cannot be intervened upon thus they do not meet the definition of cause. Best, Francis
Instructor's post : Hi Tjad! We are trying to identify which of the statements fit the definition of causality (2). Remember that the definition of cause we are using in this class requires that the 'cause' is a variable we can intervene upon (i.e. we can change somehow). For example, treatment assignment to drug or placebo, which is something we can modify. However, variables like sex cannot be intervened upon thus they do not meet the definition of cause. Best, Francis
Upvotes:
3

Title: Linking forum posts -casebiostat-03-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
'The method for collecting and applying evidence (data) to generate relative support for alternative hypotheses about the natural world' This should be false because scientific method is only about to support alternative hypothesis. Scientific method can also support null hypothesis.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi, In this case, we are using alternative in its literal (not statistical) meaning, so that alternative hypotheses are different hypotheses you can choose from. Best, Francis
Instructor's post : Hi, In this case, we are using alternative in its literal (not statistical) meaning, so that alternative hypotheses are different hypotheses you can choose from. Best, Francis
